body: My excuses @akedin I have totally forgot about this one, and somehow I wasn't receiving any notifications. It is really nicer now. Thanks, Great work !
@akedin Can you please just resolve the existing conflict so I or @kennknowles can merge this immediately after.
It seems that `RedisIOTest` is failing. I'm taking a look.
Run Java PreCommit
Run Java Gradle PreCommit

To lay it out there, to use IntelliJ with and without Gradle delegation, I think the choice is this: do we want Gradle and IntelliJ to have the same output directories or not?

If yes:
 - inherit them
 - make the hints relative to `build`
 - but actually delegation and non-delegation have different subdirs

If no:
 - don't inherit them
 - set up hints for both `build` and `out` (with totally different subdirs) so it works with both delegation and not
 - I would favor explicitly controlling the IntelliJ output directories anyhow if possible, so that we aren't guessing magic strings

Gotta stop working on this for a day or more probably.

`RedisIOTest` systematically fails with:

```
org.apache.beam.sdk.Pipeline$PipelineExecutionException: redis.clients.jedis.exceptions.JedisConnectionException: java.net.SocketException: Protocol family unavailable
```
I wanted to include this in 2.3.0 but, in order to give me time to investigate, I will fix/merge this one for 2.4.0.
Rebased on latest master, should apply cleanly.

The risk of having one clobber the output directories of the other means that you'll be corrupting gradles or intellijs caches when you attempt to use both tools at the same time. It seems like using separate output directories to me makes the most sense but others may have different opinions.

One request I have for checkstyle is that we have a tool that automatically can format any file into acceptable style. My very favorite checkstyle rule is that the file has be exactly formatted according to a tool (and then you can skip checkstyle and just diff against the tool).

The only tool I know of that does a good job is `google-java-format`. This has nothing to do with the fact that I work for Google - I would use it anyhow. The most important thing is that I want things to be readable but I also never want to have to talk about that fact.

ohhh, this is a PR I don't noticed for long time. 
@xumingming  could you restate the code and I'll verify it again quickly.

R: @robertwb 

Note that this change depends on https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4602, which is not yet merged.  I will rebase after that change gets in.

Reviewed 2 of 27 files at r1, 3 of 7 files at r2, 4 of 6 files at r3.
Review status: 9 of 25 files reviewed at latest revision, 7 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed.

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/JsonMetricsSerializer.java, line 29 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4548#-L4lluU2UEFYijwXu-hj:-L4lluU2UEFYijwXu-hk:buge1ex) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/452d524e9e93c8e415be809a41117be2367e64d4/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/JsonMetricsSerializer.java#L29)):*
> ```Java
> 
> /** Serialize metrics into json representation to be pushed to a backend. */
> public class JsonMetricsSerializer implements MetricsSerializer<String> {
> ```

Yuck. I've heard the arguments against using Jackson, but is this the best way we have to do json serialization? It's a problem if every open source project needs to roll its own json serialization.

A quick search reveals https://github.com/google/gson, which has an Apache-2.0 license. Would that work here?

Alternatively, I would recommend putting this JsonMetricsSerializer in a separate artifact which can include jackson.

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsPusher.java, line 79 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4548#-L4mWhVmcivKjpDBM54k:-L4mWhVmcivKjpDBM54l:b-3vahai) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/452d524e9e93c8e415be809a41117be2367e64d4/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsPusher.java#L79)):*
> ```Java
>     switch (pipelineOptions.getMetricsSink()) {
>       case "org.apache.beam.runners.core.metrics.MetricsHttpSink":
>         metricsSink = new MetricsHttpSink(pipelineOptions.getMetricsHttpSinkUrl());
> ```

This pattern for registration requires changes to runners-core for any new sink. Could you use a pattern where new sinks can be registered dynamically? For example, see how the --runner pipeline option implements a Default.InstanceFactory: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/fd85372b377c78515a0fb4418353509532d8f841/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/options/PipelineOptions.java#L228

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsPusher.java, line 82 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4548#-L4mXJjriEP9_vXEL0Ef:-L4mXJjriEP9_vXEL0Eg:b-i7m3ah) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/452d524e9e93c8e415be809a41117be2367e64d4/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsPusher.java#L82)):*
> ```Java
>         break;
>       default:
>         metricsSink = new DummyMetricsSink();
> ```

For the default case we should incur as little overhead as possible since the infrastructure isn't actually being used. A couple recommendations:

1) Instead of a DummyMetricsSink, implement a NoopMetricsSink which doesn't consume the input iterable and doesn't do any work.
2) Don't register any sink and don't even call the the start() method to avoid the polling thread doing metrics aggregation logic.

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsPusher.java, line 87 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4548#-L4mWTUhgWE1ptLmr6Jj:-L4mWTUhgWE1ptLmr6Jk:bqqbyna) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/452d524e9e93c8e415be809a41117be2367e64d4/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsPusher.java#L87)):*
> ```Java
>         pipelineOptions.getMetricsPushPeriod() != null
>             ? pipelineOptions.getMetricsPushPeriod()
>             : DEFAULT_PERIOD;
> ```

How about make this the default value in the PipelineOptions instead? This would put the entire configuration in one place.

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsSink.java, line 28 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4548#-L4mZncWXgIUYuM5Qf8j:-L4mZncWXgIUYuM5Qf8k:b-89m099) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/452d524e9e93c8e415be809a41117be2367e64d4/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsSink.java#L28)):*
> ```Java
>  */
> 
> public abstract class MetricsSink<OutputT> implements Serializable{
> ```

From the provided implementations, I'm not yet convinced the functionality provided by this base class is worth constraining the API for MetricsSink implementations. I recommend converting this to an interface with a single writeMetrics() method, and let MetricsSink implementations decide how to instantiate a serializer, etc.

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsSink.java, line 33 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4548#-L4mZPpVMf5W69kGkB5E:-L4mZPpVMf5W69kGkB5F:bl4f0d1) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/452d524e9e93c8e415be809a41117be2367e64d4/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MetricsSink.java#L33)):*
> ```Java
> 
>   void writeMetrics(MetricQueryResults metricQueryResults) throws Exception {
>     if (metricsSerializer != null) {
> ```

Do you expect valid scenarios where a MetricsSink initializes itself with a null serializer? This seems like it will silently mask configuration issues.

---

*[sdks/java/build-tools/src/main/resources/beam/findbugs-filter.xml, line 42 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4548#-L4mb9MCqXj2PrgZGqt6:-L4mb9MCqXj2PrgZGqt7:b-6v4uyt) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/452d524e9e93c8e415be809a41117be2367e64d4/sdks/java/build-tools/src/main/resources/beam/findbugs-filter.xml#L42)):*
> ```XML
> 	-->
>   <Match>
>     <Class name="org.apache.beam.runners.core.metrics.MetricsPusher"/>
> ```

This seems very odd that this suppression is needed. I don't see anything clever about this code that would confuse FindBugs. If you remove this suppression, does FindBugs fail?

---


*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4548)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

r: @robertwb 
This PR is an alternative of PR 4387. In this PR, `MetricContainer`s are registered on the StateSampler, and accessed via the step name (this ensures that they are cleaned up with the StateSampler). 

In PR 4387, MetricsContainers are attached to the current ScopedState.
